repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Energy Sector Deregulation and
            Privatization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Energy Sector Deregulation and
            Privatization Project's outcome was rate
            unsatisfactory. The support for both an independent
            regulatory system and privatization proved to be weak, and
            the government did not live up to its commitment. Some key
            lessons include: 1) Build-own-operates and independent power
            producers can be a useful vehicle to mobilize additional
            resources for the electricity sector and shift the
            construction and technical performance risks to private
            investors. However, structuring them may require a lot of
            time and senior management attention, and involve numerous
            agreements, which is one reason why they are not necessarily
            at a low-cost solution. 2) In an electricity system that
            depends on the supply by private firms, this private failure
            can become a public problem. It is therefore necessary for
            the Bank to pay attention to the technical aspects of such
            projects. 3) In lending to privately owned utilities, the
            Bank should avoid creating a new financial window which
            might end up being used for only one transaction or a very
            small number of transactions. 4) Care should be exercised in
            undertaking Operation Evaluation Department performance
            audit reports prior to the implementation completion report.
            5) While a comprehensive and innovative approach to sector
            development has obvious attractions, it may exceed the
            country's implemntation capacity. It may also require
            more supervision resources than the Bank is prepared to allocate.

728954.trustfund:
TF025380-PHRD-TA FOR PRIVATE SECTOR
            ENERGY DEV.,TF022177-PHRD 2-GUARANTEE TRUST FUND 1/PFG,TF022150-PHRD 2-PRIVATIZATION PROGRAM
            I/CFS CONL'T

abstracts.cdata!:
Financial closing for the 60-megawatt,
            diesel-powered power station project occurred on October 14,
            1994, setting several milestones for Jamaica and the Bank:
            It is the largest private infrastructure project in Jamaica
            to date; it is the first build-own-operate project in
            Jamaica; it is the first Bank-supported build-own-operate
            project to reach financial closure; it is the first project
            jointly supported by the Bank and MIGA; and it is the first
            Bank loan to facilitate access to low-cost construction
            financing provided by commercial lenders. This Note
            discusses the project, the financing plan, and the role of
            the World Bank Group.

5079279.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Energy Sector Deregulation and
            Privatization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will comprise of:  (a) the
            installation of about 120 MW of power generation capacity
            consisting of a 60 MW low-speed diesel plant in the private
            sector and a 60 MW combustion turbine plant, of which the
            first 30 MW will be in the public sector and the second 30
            MW will be in the private sector; (b) the installation of
            associated transmission lines and substations; (c)
            establishment and operation of the Private Sector Energy
            Fund to provide long-term financing for private power
            projects; and (d) consulting services to:  (i) assist in the
            operation of the Private Sector Energy Fund; (ii) prepare
            the 60 MW diesel power station and the second 30 MW
            combustion turbine unit for solicitation; (iii) assist the
            Government of Jamaica in the solicitation, evaluation,
            appraisal, negotiation and supervision of the private
            projects; (iv) develop a contractual framework for the
            build-own-operate projects and a regulatory framework for
            the operation of the power sector; and (v) develop and
            implement a privatization strategy for the Jamaica Public
            Service Company and Petrojam.
